headline: 7 GOP candidates for Senate debate on multiple issues
author: Trevor Hubert
sentences:
“We may not agree on all of the issues, but in the totality of the America First movement of putting you as American citizens, we the people, first, heck yeah, I’m proud to have his endorsement.”
Mr. Gibbons defended his endorsement from U.S. Sen. Rand Paul (R., Ky.), and Ms. Timken defended her association with former Trump campaign manager Corey Lewandowski.

Ms. Timken and Mr. Gibbons cited their claims of 2020 presidential election irregularities, while the other candidates said that they believed the election was “stolen” from former President Donald Trump, with the exception of Mr. Dolan, who said that Joe Biden is a legitimate president, but called him a “failed” president.

Debating a range of issues ranging from the 2020 presidential election to immigration and taxes, seven Republican candidates for U.S. Senate took the stage at Central State University in Wilberforce, Ohio on Monday night to show voters why they deserve to become the successor to retiring Sen.

In his response to the election question, Mr. Pukita said that part of the issue is that the country, state, and GOP have been “hijacked by corrupt leadership.”
“I want to go to Washington and eradicate that kind of thinking, personality, and lack of ethics,” he said.

The GOP primary victor will face one of three candidates seeking the Democratic nomination: U.S. Rep. Tim Ryan (D., Youngstown area), Columbus area consumer protection attorney Morgan Harper, and Columbus area information technology executive Traci (TJ) Johnson.

Mr. Trump has not endorsed any candidate, but has stated that he would refuse to endorse Mr. Dolan because of the Dolan family’s decision to change the Cleveland baseball team nickname from Indians to Guardians.

“I think one of the things that has to happen is to finish the wall [on the Southern border], because [illegal immigrants] are coming through the cracks,” Mr. Gibbons said about the current state of immigration.

When debate moderator Karen Kasler fact-checked candidates on the election issue, saying that many of the claims being made were unverified or already debunked, she was met with a rain of boos from the audience.

“All of the out-of-touch millionaires embarrassed themselves tonight as they injected more nasty attacks into their chaotic and out-of-control primary,” Ohio Democratic Party spokesman Michael Beyer said.

As the debate continued on, the candidates fielded questions on immigration, taxes, religion, the U.S. Supreme Court, and the Jan. 6th attack on the U.S. Capitol.
